contents.context:
The majority of EU member states believe reopening schools has not led to any significant rise in COVID-19 cases, at least for now.
Education ministers of 22 European countries concluded this in Monday's videoconference following students' gradual return to classrooms about two weeks ago.
17 of the countries are taking a more tentative approach, allowing only certain grades to go back to school namely kindergartens, elementary schools and the final years of high school.
Despite the wave of school reopenings, there hasn't been any large spike in cases or any other negative impact in the region.

The Croatian education minister, chairing a meeting of her European counterparts, stressed the importance of the quarantine measures that schools have taken to keep them safe.
That includes schools running classes with fewer students, usually in groups of around 15, as well as closely following the government guidelines.

However, she said the "positive results must be treated with caution", saying that it may be too early to make a final conclusion.

In the UK and France, there is still much debate over school safety.
Just one week after some 40-thousand preschools and primary schools opened last week, France has seen about 70 new cases linked to 7 institutions.
But the French education minister Jean-Michel Blanquer said the outbreak is only minor, and that it is more damaging for students to stay home than go to school.
Over in the UK, the government's plan to resume primary schools starting June 1st is facing pressure from teachers' and doctors' unions.

Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
EU ministers say school reopenings have not triggered spike in COVID-19 cases
Updated: 2020-05-19 17:10:54 KST

contents.context:
U.S. biotech company Moderna says there have been some promising early results from its first human tests for a potential vaccine for COVID-19.
According to Moderna, the vaccine produced virus-fighting antibodies in all 45 participants.
Healthy volunteers between the ages of 18 to 55 were separated into three groups and each received a 25, 100 or 250 microgram dose of the potential vaccine.
The results showed the levels of antibodies in the participants were similar or greater than those in patients who had recovered from the virus.
The vaccine also produced neutralizing antibodies in at least eight participants, which is considered important in acquiring protection.

"Our anticipation is that it will be in the millions by the end of this year. It could be as high as a billion doses in 2021."

Approved by the U.S. FDA last month, Moderna will proceed with the second phase involving 600 people and it expects a third to begin in July, if the second phase goes well.
It said that, if the vaccine is found to be effective and safe, it could be ready for commercial use in early 2021.

Other bio tech firms around the world have also started human safety trials. According to a report by the Wall Street Journal, eight companies are developing a vaccine based on a new technology.
This includes Pfizer's trial involving 360 volunteers across the U.S., and the first subjects have already been injected with a dose.
Britain's AstraZeneca also produce 30 million vaccine doses in the U.K. by September.

Bio tech companies in South Korea are also accelerating their vaccine and treatment development.
A consortium comprised of vaccine research institutes and medicine manufacturing companies has announced it has completed manufacturing the technical ingredients for a clinical phase 1 trial of the drug.
Choi Jeong-yoon, Arirang News.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Moderna's vaccine testing produces COVID-19 antibodies in all 45 human participants
Updated: 2020-05-19 17:08:19 KST

contents.context:
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says the downturn in the U.S. economy is unprecedented in modern historyand is worse than "any recession since World War 2."
In testimony for a congressional hearing Tuesday, he said that, over the last 2 months, more than 20 million people have lost their jobs reversing almost a decade of gains.
He also said COVID-19 has massively disrupted financial markets and halted the smooth flow of credit.
Powell said the Fed plans to keep interest rates at almost zero percent until the economy bounces back to reasonable levels.

Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. economy in worst shape since WWII; Fed will maintain almost 0% rates: Powell
Updated: 2020-05-19 10:05:51 KST

contents.context:
With the 73rd World Health Assembly taking place virtually for the first time in its history on Monday, UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres slammed some countries for brushing off the WHO's advice during the global COVID-19 pandemic.
He insisted the pandemic should serve as a "wake-up call" to a world which needs to be more united in its response.

"COVID-19 must be a wakeup call. It is time for an end to this hubris. Our deep feelings of powerlessness must lead to greater humility. Deadly global threats require a new unity and solidarity."

The UN chief also reiterated the need to support the WHO, which he described as "irreplaceable".

"The WHO is irreplaceable. It needs enhanced resources, particularly to provide support to developing countries, which must be our greatest concern. We are as strong as the weakest health systems."

Despite the call for unity, U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar slammed China for its lack of transparency in regards to the outbreak, stressing that Beijing's actions cost the lives of many people around the world.
The criticism was made indirectly, but it was clear which country Azar was referencing.

"In an apparent attempt to conceal this outbreak, at least one member state made a mockery of their transparency obligations with tremendous costs for the entire world."

He also heaped blame on the WHO for the agency's lack of information sharing and transparency, calling it "intolerable".
Azar demanded changes be made at the WHO, accusing it of failing to obtain the information the world needed as the outbreak started to filter out.
Despite the verbal attack on China and the WHO, Chinese President Xi Jinping defended Beijing's handling of the pandemic.

"All along, China has acted with openness, transparency, and responsibility. We have provided the information to WHO and relevant countries in a most timely fashion. We have done everything in our power to support and assist countries in need."

President Xi said China will provide two billion U.S. dollars of international assistance within two years to help with the COVID-19 response.
In addition, he vowed that vaccine "development and deployment" in China, when complete, will be made available for the public good both inside and outside China.
He added that any COVID-19 vaccine developed by China would be accessible and affordable for developing nations.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Fierce exchange between U.S., China during World Health Assembly over COVID-19; UN chief calls for unity
Updated: 2020-05-19 10:03:02 KST

contents.context:
UNESCO and the International Council of Museums says 13 percent of museums worldwide could NEVER reopen, adding that museums have been hit hard by the COVID-19 pandemic with nearly 90 percent of them shut down so far.
Marking International Museum Day on Monday, the agencies said this will lead to a massive job loss for people working at such cultural spaces globally.
The UNESCO chief said museums play a fundamental role in the resilience of societies, and it's the job of UNESCO to help them cope with the unprecedented crisis.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
13% of museums worldwide may never reopen after COVID-19 pandemic: UNESCO
Updated: 2020-05-19 10:01:30 KST

contents.context:
Emirates, one of the world's biggest airlines, is considering whether to cut 30-thousand jobs, or roughly a third of its workforce due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Describing it as the deepest cut in the global airline industry caused by the pandemic, Bloomberg said Monday that Emirates' decision is aimed at preparing the company for a possible prolonged recession in the tourism sector.
In April, British Airways said it would cut up to 12-thousand jobs.
Four major airlines in the U.S. have asked over 100-thousand employees to go on voluntary short-term leave or to take early retirement.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Emirates mulls cutting 30,000 jobs as COVID-19 pandemic saps demand
Updated: 2020-05-19 08:43:10 KST

contents.context:
U.S. biotech company Moderna says there have been some promising early results from its first human tests for a potential vaccine for COVID-19.
It said the vaccine produced virus-fighting antibodies in all 45 participants that were similar or greater than those in patients who had recovered from the virus.
The vaccine also produced neutralizing antibodies in at least eight participants, which is considered important in acquiring protection.
Approved by the FDA last month, Moderna will proceed with the second phase of testing involving 600 people.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Moderna's vaccine testing produces COVID-19 antibodies in all 45 participants
Updated: 2020-05-19 07:09:11 KST

contents.context:
The American ride-hailing company Uber says it will be cutting three-thousand more jobs because of the COVID-19 pandemic, less than two weeks after its initial round of layoffs.
In an email to its employees Monday, Uber's CEO said the company will also be shutting or consolidating 45 of its offices around the world.
Uber's latest round of cuts come after it announced earlier this month that it will be laying off 37-hundred employees or 14-percent of its workforce.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Uber cuts 3,000 more jobs, shuts 45 offices during COVID-19 crunch
Updated: 2020-05-19 07:05:36 KST

contents.context:
Huawei says the latest round of U.S. sanctions threaten its own business and the entire global industries.
Speaking at this year's virtual Huawei Analyst Summit, the Chinese company said the U.S. was shooting itself in the foot with the sanctions.

"The U.S. is leveraging its own technological strengths in an attempt to crush companies outside its own borders. This will only serve to undermine the trust that international companies place in U.S. technology and U.S. supply chains. Ultimately we believe that this will harm U.S. interests."

Huawei added that the decision is arbitrary and harmful.
The response comes as the Trump administration imposed new restrictions on the Chinese tech giant last week.
They severely limit Huawei's ability to use U.S. technology to design and manufacture chips for its devices.
U.S. intelligence agencies say the sanctions are needed as the Chinese government could use Huawei to spy.

Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Huawei says new U.S. sanctions will have serious impact on wide number of global industries
Updated: 2020-05-19 05:58:53 KST

contents.context:
We begin a discussion on an issue making headlines.
The number of fatalities caused by COVID-19 have been declining, but new infections continue to occur.
Nevertheless, governments and their populations have been itching to ease restrictions.
Countries have been loosening quarantine measures and letting non-essential businesses reopen, but there are concerns about a second wave.
South Korea, Singapore and China, which contained the virus at an early stage, have recently experienced a resurgence of cluster infections.
The WHO warned Europe this week that it should brace itself for a stronger and potentially deadlier second wave of COVID-19.
To discuss what a second wave would look like and if it's inevitable, we connect with Professor Peter Collignon at Australian National University Medical School, who is also an infectious Diseases physician and microbiologist at Canberra Hospital.
We also have joining us, Dr. Bruce Y. Lee, Professor of Health Policy and Management at City University New York, who is a systems modeler and a Senior Contributor for Forbes.

Prof. Collignon: South Korea, which eased social distancing requirements this month saw a spike in cases linked to nightclubs in Seoul. We even saw a fourth-hand transmission take place. Singapore, Hong Kong and China have also seen a resurgence of cases. This has given rise to worries about a dreaded second wave. Is this really the making of a second wave, and what lessons can we take away from the sudden surge of cases?

Prof. Lee: The Trump administration has been adamant about the necessity of reopening economies and your Health Secretary Alex Azar said that if lockdowns continue, it would hurt the capacity to address other health needs. But hospitals are already overwhelmed as it is and a report you recently published in Health Affairs shows how medical costs could surge to the hundreds of billions of dollars if coronavirus infections soar significantly. Is it wise, then, for governments to push for business as usual for hte sake of the economy?

Prof. Collignon: Based on the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic, some have projected we'll see a stronger, a more deadly version of the virus in the second wave, especially in European countries. Does this mean more infections and fatalities will occur? And in countries like South Korea and Singapore, where few people have immunity, would a second wave be more severe?

Prof. Lee: If the number of cases grows, how will this affect the response to a second wave? It seems each country or region has its own standard of easing lockdowns. THe WHO has called for a scientific, or evidence-based approach to easing restrictions. Should the reproduction number be the standard-bearer?

Prof. Collignon: In the midst of these concerns, students in Europe are going back to school and South Korea is also having high school students resume offline classes from Wednesday. There seems there are mixed opinions about this.
What does science tell us about how children's chances of being infected? What precautions should be taken as schools reopen?

Prof. Lee: How can governments be better prepared than they were the first time? And until a vaccine is out and ready for use, can we expect to see repeated waves of lockdowns with a resurgence of infections?

That's all we have time for today but it's been an informative discussion.
Thank you for joining us Professor Peter Collignon and Professor Bruce Y. Lee from Canberra and New York.

Reporter : osy@arirang.com
contents.headline:
How can we prepare for stronger second wave of COVID-19?
Updated: 2020-05-19 05:41:31 KST

contents.context:
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell says the U.S. economy might start to bounce back in the third quarter, but a full recovery might not be possible until there's a COVID-19 vaccine.
This was in an interview Sunday with the CBS program '60 Minutes.'
As for a vaccine, the director of Johns Hopkins University's center for health security says one could be developed by the end of the year.
Speaking to broadcaster NBC, Dr. Tom Inglesby said such rapid development is "not realistic" under normal circumstances, but this unique situation might make it possible.
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. economy might not fully recover until the development of COVID-19 vaccine: Jerome Powell
Updated: 2020-05-18 13:28:10 KST

contents.context:
Every year, the World Health Assembly brings together representatives from the WHO's 194 member states in Geneva to discuss a wide range of health topics.
However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic,.. which has now infected over 4.7 million people and killed more than 300-thousand worldwide, the meeting will be held via teleconference for the first time.
While the meeting will focus mostly on the COVID-19 pandemic, there's another major issue at hand.

"China could have prevented the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people worldwide. China could have spared the world descent into global economic malaise. They had a choice, but instead, China covered up the outbreak in Wuhan, its National Health Commission ordered virus samples destroyed on January 3rd."

Number of member states, including the United States, Australia, Canada, France and Germany are set to question China's response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and probe Beijing about where it actually originated from.
Many have accused China of concealing the facts and numbers, leading to the massive global outbreak.
They are also set to grill WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus over allegations he sided with China during the early stages of the pandemic.
Beijing has continuously denied the claims, saying it's too early to draw a conclusion on the source of the virus.
The Chinese government insists it's an issue for scientists to resolve, not politicians.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
World Health Assembly to convene online amid COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-18 09:34:53 KST
